dataset.title: Archaeological shovel test data for Little Sapelo Island, Mary Hammock, Patterson Island, and Pumpkin Hammock; Spring 2007, Summer 2007 and 2008

abstract.para: The purpose of this study was to determine the human occupational history of Little Sapelo Island, Mary Hammock, Patterson Island, and Pumpkin Hammock in McIntosh County, GA. During the Spring of 2007 and Summers of 2007 and 2008, a systematic archaeological shovel test survey was performed at a closely-spaced interval of 20 meters. The shovel test grid was laid out using a Trimble GPS, in accordance with the Universal Trans Mercator coordinate system Zone 17, and the North American Datum of 1927 (with a typical accuracy between 1 and 6 m). Teams of two people would go to these locations, dig holes (typically 50 cm in diameter and 1 m deep), and put the soil through wire hardware cloth with a mesh size of 0.6 cm (i.e., 0.25 inch). All cultural material (except shell) were collected and put in labeled plastic bags. Only some shell samples were kept for future analysis. Ceramics were classified to determine surface treatment/ decoration, temper, and rim form, with the ultimate goal of determining their period of use. All of the data related to these shovel tests were entered into a spreadsheet, and that spreadsheet was turned into an ArcGIS point shapefile for analysis. These data are available for professional archaeologists only. Please contact the investigator by E-mail if you would like a copy of these data.

intellectualRights.para: All publications based on this data set must cite the contributor and Georgia Coastal Ecosystems LTER project, and two copies of the manuscript must be submitted to the GCE-LTER Information Management Office.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Overall bounding box describing the geographic region within the Georgia Coastal Ecosystems LTER study domain represented in data set ANT-GCES-1308, based on the maximum geographic extents of all site polygons referenced in the data set

section.title: Shovel Testing
section.para: This is an archaeological method to locate subsurface cultural material. A grid was laid out using a Trimble GPS, in accordance with the Universal Trans Mercator coordinate system Zone 17, and the North American Datum of 1927 (with a typical accuracy between 1 and 6 m). The shovel test numbers were written on flags, and the flags were placed at intervals of 20 meters acorss the entire island (this was the grid). Teams of two people would go to these locations, record the locations noted on the flag, and dig holes 1 meter deep, and 50 cm in diameter. The soil dug from these holes was put through wire hardware cloth with a mesh size of 0.25 inch (i.e., 0.6 cm). All cultural material (except shell) was collected, put in plastic bags, and labeled (with the date, names of the workers, and shovel test location and/ or number). Some shell samples from each shovel test were kept for future analysis.

methodStep.instrumentation: Trimble ProXT GPS; manufacturer: Trimble (model: ProXT (PN 52240-20)); parameter: Latitude (accuracy: 1-6 meters, range: 0-90)
Trimble ProXT GPS; manufacturer: Trimble (model: ProXT (PN 52240-20)); parameter: Longitude (accuracy: 1-6 meters, range: 0-180)
Trimble GPS, shovel with a spade head, wire hardware cloth of 0.25 inch mesh size, paper and plastic artifact bags, sharpies, and pencils.

section.title: Cultural Material Processing
section.para: Each day, all of the cultural materials collected from the shovel testing were processed for future analysis. This consisted of lighlty scrubbing all artifacts, bone, and shell with toothbrushes and tap water. The cultural material were left out of their bags, on plastic trays, to dry overnight. The next day, the cultural material were separated into two main categories: prehistoric (Native American) and historic (European and American). Since the vast majority of these materials were broken ceramics (known as sherds), they were counted and weighed to the nearest tenth with a digital scale. Sherds that could fit through wire hardware cloth with a mesh size of 0.5 inch (i.e., 1.3 cm) were recorded as ceramic “residuals,” and not included in the count and weight measurements. Finally, all cultural materials were put back in their respective bags.

methodStep.instrumentation: Toothbrushes, water, plastic trays, wire hardware cloth of 0.25 inch mesh size, and digital scales (battery-powered).

section.title: Data Entry
section.para: All of the data related to the shovel tests were entered into an Excel spreadsheet. This included shovel test location and/ or shovel test number, the amount of shell found (presence or absence/ shell midden/ and shell midden thickness), the presence of prehistoric artifacts, hisotric artifacts, animal bones, and charcoal, and the counts and weights of prehistoric and historic pottery sherds.

section.title: Ceramic Analysis
section.para: Native American ceramic sherds were analyzed to determine surface treatment/ decoration, temper, and rim form, with the ultimate goal of determining their period of use. The ceramic typology developed by DePratter (1991) for the northern coast of Georgia was used, along with additional sources (Deagan and Thomas 2009; Guerrero and Thomas 2008; Williams and Thompson 1999). This analysis was performed in multiple locations: on Sapelo Island (McIntosh County, GA), at the Laboratory of Archaeology (University of Georgia, Athens), and Thompson's archaeology lab (University of West Florida, Pensacola).

methodStep.instrumentation: Electric lights, and Microsoft Excel 2003 and 2007.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: GCE Study Site GCE_Domain -- GCE Domain, Sapelo Island, Georgia. Primary study area of the Georgia Coastal Ecosystems Long Term Ecological Research Program

section.title: Archaeological Survey
section.para: A systematic archaeological survey was performed to understand changes in human occupation of the island over time.
Shovel tests were dug at 20-m intervals, to depths of 1m, up to 50cm in diameter, and over the entire expanse of each location.

project.title: Georgia Coastal Ecosystems LTER Project II

abstract.para: The Georgia Coastal Ecosystems (GCE) LTER program, located on the central Georgia coast, was established in 2000. The study domain encompasses three adjacent sounds (Altamaha, Doboy, Sapelo) and includes upland (mainland, barrier islands, marsh hammocks), intertidal (fresh, brackish and salt marsh) and submerged (river, estuary, continental shelf) habitats. Patterns and processes in this complex landscape vary spatially within and between sites, and temporally on multiple scales (tidal, diurnal, seasonal, and interannual). Overlain on this spatial and temporal variation are long-term trends caused by climate change, sea level rise, and human alterations of the landscape. These long-term trends are likely to manifest in many ways, including changes in water quality, river discharge, runoff and tidal inundation patterns throughout the estuarine landscape. The overarching goal of the GCE program is to understand the mechanisms by which variation in the quality, source and amount of both fresh and salt water create temporal and spatial variability in estuarine habitats and processes, in order to predict directional changes that will occur in response to long-term shifts in estuarine salinity patterns.

funding.para: This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under grant numbers OCE-9982133 and OCE-0620959. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed in the material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

dataTable.entityDescription: Archaeological shovel test data for Little Sapelo, Spring 2007

online.onlineDescription: Spreadsheet comma-separated value (CSV) text file with a five line header containing the data set title, column titles, units and column types

description.para: Data file post-processing in the GCE-LTER Information Management Office

abstract.para: The GCE Data Toolbox is a comprehensive library of functions for metadata-based analysis quality control, transformation and management of ecological data sets. The toolbox is based on the GCE Data Structure, a MATLAB specification for storing tabular data along with all information required to interpret the data and generate formatted metadata (documentation). Metadata fields in the structure are queried by toolbox functions for all operations, allowing functions to process and format values appropriately based on the type of information they represent. This semantic processing approach supports highly automated and intelligent data analysis and ensures data set validity throughout all processing steps.

description.para: 02/26/2014: new GCE Data Structure 1.1 created ("newstruct")
02/26/2014: 769 rows imported from ASCII data file "ANT-GCES-1308.txt" ("imp_ascii")
02/26/2014: 70 metadata fields in file header parsed ("parse_header")
02/26/2014: data structure validated ("gce_valid")
02/26/2014: Q/C flagging criteria applied, "flags" field updated ("dataflag")
02/26/2014: manually edited data set metadata ("ui_editmetadata")
02/26/2014: imported Dataset, Project, Site, Study, Status, Supplement metadata descriptors from the GCE Metabase ("imp_gcemetadata")
02/26/2014: updated 56 metadata fields in the Dataset, Project, Site, Status, Study, Supplement sections ("addmeta")
02/26/2014: updated 4 metadata fields ("addmeta")
02/26/2014: updated 15 metadata fields in the Status, Data sections to reflect attribute metadata ("updatecols")
02/26/2014: parsed and formatted metadata ("listmeta")

02/26/2014: flags for columns Shell_Thickness, Prehistoric_Sherd_Count, Prehistoric_Sherd_Weight, Historic_Sherd_Count and Historic_Sherd_Weight converted to data columns, flag codes updated in metadata ("flags2cols")

Quality control analysis was performed using the GCE Data Toolbox for MATLAB software. Column data types are validated upon importing the table into MATLAB, and qualifier flags are automatically generated for data values based on QA/QC criteria for each data column pre-defined in metadata templates (e.g. value range checks, sanity checks, pattern checks). Qualifier flags are also assigned to values that are imputed or derived, revised, or otherwise differ from values in the original data submission. A column of coded qualifier flags is generated and included in the data table if flags are assigned to any value in a data column.

abstract.para: The GCE Data Toolbox is a comprehensive library of functions for metadata-based analysis quality control, transformation and management of ecological data sets. The toolbox is based on the GCE Data Structure, a MATLAB specification for storing tabular data along with all information required to interpret the data and generate formatted metadata (documentation). Metadata fields in the structure are queried by toolbox functions for all operations, allowing functions to process and format values appropriately based on the type of information they represent. This semantic processing approach supports highly automated and intelligent data analysis and ensures data set validity throughout all processing steps.

09/06/2013: Q/C flagging criteria applied, "flags" field updated ("dataflag")
09/06/2013: imported Dataset, Project, Site, Study, Status, Supplement metadata descriptors from the GCE Metabase ("imp_gcemetadata")
09/06/2013: updated 56 metadata fields in the Dataset, Project, Site, Status, Study, Supplement sections ("addmeta")
09/06/2013: manually edited data set metadata ("ui_editmetadata")
09/06/2013: updated 4 metadata fields ("addmeta")
09/06/2013: updated 15 metadata fields in the Status, Data sections to reflect attribute metadata ("updatecols")
09/06/2013: parsed and formatted metadata ("listmeta")
09/06/2013: flags for columns Shell_Weight, Prehistoric_Sherd_Count and Prehistoric_Sherd_Weight converted to data columns, flag codes updated in metadata ("flags2cols")

Quality control analysis was performed using the GCE Data Toolbox for MATLAB software. Column data types are validated upon importing the table into MATLAB, and qualifier flags are automatically generated for data values based on QA/QC criteria for each data column pre-defined in metadata templates (e.g. value range checks, sanity checks, pattern checks). Qualifier flags are also assigned to values that are imputed or derived, revised, or otherwise differ from values in the original data submission. A column of coded qualifier flags is generated and included in the data table if flags are assigned to any value in a data column.
